item.title: Spanish singles found a new dating strategy. It’s in the fruit aisle.
item.dc:creator: Leo Sands
item.description: The method, which grew popular on TikTok, involves placing a pineapple in your cart at the Mercadona grocery store at night. People say it’s a reaction against dating apps.

item.title: Ukraine’s foreign minister resigns in largest shake-up since war began
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady
item.description: The reorganization of the administration comes as Russia unleashes a new wave of aerial attacks on cities, including one on Lviv that killed seven overnight.

item.title: All 72 deaths in U.K.’s Grenfell Tower fire avoidable, final report says
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam
item.description: The burning of Grenfell Tower and the deaths of dozens horrified Britain and put renewed scrutiny on building codes and safety measures.

item.title: Which countries have suspended or restricted arms sales to Israel?
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih, Leo Sands
item.description: The U.K. is the latest country to suspend some weapons exports, amid scrutiny over military aid to Israel as the war in Gaza nears the one-year mark.

item.title: Back to school in Ukraine’s embattled Kharkiv means heading underground
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Johnson, Anastacia Galouchka
item.description: After years of distance learning, Kharkiv’s students finally get back to school — in a purpose built underground bunker safe from the Russian drones and missiles.

item.title: Elton John recovering from vision loss in one eye after severe infection
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: The 77-year-old singer said he is “feeling positive” about the progress he has made, but it will take some time before sight returns to one eye.

item.title: Netanyahu still wants more war
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The Israeli leader’s critics argue he would rather prolong the war to assuage his far-right allies (and keep hold of power) than clinch a deal that stops hostilities and frees the remaining hostages.

item.title: China hosts African leaders to rekindle ‘Belt and Road’ outreach
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd, Vic Chiang
item.description: By feting African leaders and announcing new investment deals and partnerships, Beijing is trying to strengthen its influence in global trade and geopolitics.

item.title: No X in Brazil? No problem, Brazilians say.
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy
item.description: The platform formerly known as Twitter once dominated Brazilian social media, fueling nationwide protests in 2013 and propelling Jair Bolsonaro to the presidency. Less so, now.

item.title: More than 50 killed in Russian missile strike on Ukrainian city of Poltava
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Johnson, Tetiana Burianova , Siobhán O'Grady, Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Two missiles hit a military educational institution and nearby hospital. President Volodymyr Zelensky called for lifting restrictions on Western-supplied weapons.

item.title: Former aide to N.Y. governors charged with secretly helping China
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.description: Linda Sun and her husband, Chris Hu, are accused of accepting millions of dollars in kickbacks in exchange for pushing political actions to benefit China.

item.title: As U.S. readies last cease-fire push, Netanyahu digs in on border demands
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Loveday Morris, John Hudson
item.description: The Israeli prime minister’s insistence that troops stay in the Philadelphi Corridor along the Gaza-Egypt border is scuttling chances of a deal, officials say.

item.title: Lebanon detains former central bank governor accused of financial crimes
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Suzan Haidamous, Mohamad El Chamaa
item.description: Riad Salameh, who was once credited with reviving Lebanon’s post-civil-war economy, has since been blamed for the stunning collapse of its banking sector.

item.title: U.K. defends decision to restrict arms to Israel; Netanyahu calls it shameful
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Loveday Morris
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the decision to halt 30 of 350 arms export licenses was “shameful,” while Amnesty International called it insufficient.

item.title: Husband drugged wife, recruited over 70 men to rape her, prosecutors say
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: The case of Dominique Pélicot, accused of repeatedly sedating his wife and inviting men to rape her while she was unconscious, has caused outrage in France.

item.title: Venezuela orders arrest of candidate who U.S., others say won election
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: Venezuela’s public prosecutor’s office accused opposition candidate Edmundo González of usurpation and instigating disobedience, among other crimes.

item.title: 12 dead after migrant boat in English Channel capsizes
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: A boat carrying dozens of migrants capsized in the English Channel off the coast of northern France. At least two people are missing.

item.title: Anger over Oasis ticket prices sparks U.K. review of dynamic pricing
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong, Julian Mark
item.description: Delight at the Oasis reunion turned to outrage when fans found the pricing model meant some tickets had more than doubled in price while they queued online.

item.title: Harry Potter fans boo as ‘miserable muggles’ nix annual King’s Cross event
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman
item.description: The train station in London canceled its annual “Back to Hogwarts” tradition, a public announcement that the Hogwarts Express was ready to depart.

item.title: More than 100 killed in failed Congo jail break at overcrowded prison
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason, Rael Ombuor
item.description: The prison in the Congolese capital, Kinshasa, was notorious for its overcrowding, with conditions described by Amnesty International as “appalling.”

item.title: How China extended its repression into an American city
item.dc:creator: Shibani Mahtani, Meg Kelly, Cate Brown, Cate Cadell, Ellen Nakashima, Chris Dehghanpoor
item.description: Events in San Francisco illustrate how the Chinese Communist Party is willing to target people exercising their First Amendment rights in an American city.

item.title: We investigated how China silenced its critics in an American city
item.dc:creator: Washington Post staff
item.description: The events in San Francisco illustrate how the Chinese Communist Party is willing to target U.S. citizens and residents exercising their First Amendment rights.

item.title: Two U.S. Marines attacked in Turkey by nationalist youth group
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: Police detained 15 people after the assault. Video shows assailants shouting, “Yankee go home” and covering one Marine’s head in what looked like a white sack.

item.title: Turkey’s stray dogs, once ‘masters of the road,’ face new peril
item.dc:creator: Beril Eski
item.description: A new law requires municipalities to round up stray dogs and euthanize the ones that are feral. It has drawn outrage in a country where committed citizens have long cared for street animals.

item.title: Protests continue in Israel as Netanyahu faces outcry over hostage strategy
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, Shira Rubin
item.description: After Hamas killed six hostages, Israel erupted in protests over Netanyahu’s policy of using the military rather than negotiations to recover the captives.

item.title: U.K. suspends some arms sales to Israel after government review
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The move marks a shift for Britain and came as part of the new Labour government’s review of Israel’s compliance with international humanitarian law.

item.title: Putin travels to Mongolia, defying international court arrest order
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon
item.description: Signatories to the Rome Statute are expected to carry out its arrest warrants, but Mongolia has close ties to Russia.
